Statistics for Behavioral Science                             Professor Elizabeth Bauer      Clinical Assistant Professor, Faculty of Arts and Sciences, New York University   Ph.D. 2000 (Experimental Psychology), City University of New York, B.A. 1989 (Psychology), City University of New York    Bio & Publications              About the Course   This course provides students with the basic tools for evaluating data from studies in the behavioral sciences, particularly psychology. Students will gain familiarity with data description, variance and variability, significance tests, confident intervals, correlation and linear regression, analysis of variance, and other related topics. The goal is to learn the application of statistical reasoning to decision making. Current events are often used to illustrate these issues.             Study this course with others   Connect with other around the world   Meet others studying the same NYU courses as you. Help them or get help yourself if you need it.   Get help when you need it   Ask a question and get matched with someone who can answer it immediately and in real time.   Work on assignments together   There's no need to take an Open Education course alone. Learn together!                  OpenStudy is a social learning network where students ask questions, give help, and connect with other students. Clicking on the Join Study Group button will take you outside the NYU site. If you choose to participate in their discussions, please know that NYU is not affiliated with OpenStudy and is not responsible for the content and features provided by the site.                                                           Get Started                      Choose a lecture from this course           Lecture 1 - Introduction Lecture 2 - Frequency Tables, Graphs, and Distributions Lecture 3 - Measures of Central Tendency and Variability (I) Lecture 4 - Measures of Central Tendency and Variability (II) Lecture 5 - Standardized Scores and Normal Distribution (I) Lecture 6 - Standardized Scores and Normal Distribution (II) Lecture 7 - Intro to Hypothesis Testing: One Group Z-Test Lecture 8 - Interval Test and the T-Distribution Lecture 9 - T-Test for Two Independent Sample Means Lecture 10 - Statistical Power and Effect Size (I) Lecture 11 - Statistical Power and Effect Size (II) Lecture 12 - Linear Correlation Lecture 13 - Linear Regression (I) Lecture 14 - Linear Regression (II) Lecture 15 - Matched T-Test Lecture 16 - One-Way Independent ANOVA Lecture 17 - Multiple Comparisons Lecture 18 - Linear Contrasts Lecture 19 - Two-Way ANOVA Lecture 20 - Interactions Lecture 21 - Repeated Measure ANOVA (I) Lecture 22 - Repeated Measure ANOVA (II) Lecture 23 - Chi-Square                             Course Readings     Explaining Psychology Statistics (3rd ed.), Cohen, B. Social and Behavioral Sciences                                                                                                        NYU.edu requires JavaScript be enabled in your browser in order to use important features of the site. JavaScript is either disabled or not supported by your browser. For instructions on how to enable JavaScript in your browser, click here .                New York University    Skip to Content   Skip to Search   Skip to Sub Navigation              Global Institute of Public Health                       Search NYU                    Pages |    People                                                                Bread Crumbs          Global Institute of Public Health   /   Academic Programs   /   Master of Public Health   /   Academics   /   Concentrations                       Sub Navigation                                 Community and International Health                       Epidemiology                       Global Health Leadership                       Public Health Nutrition                       Social and Behavioral Sciences                                                                 Social and Behavioral Sciences       The Social and Behavioral Sciences (SBS) track emphasizes research and focuses on the social, behavioral, and structural determinants of health. Students will be prepared to work on research and evaluation projects drawing on the social and behavioral sciences.        Upon graduation, students will be able to do the following in both local and global settings:      Apply theories,  concepts and models from a range of social and behavioral disciplines that  are used in public health research and practice.   Assess  the causes of social and behavioral factors that affect health of  individuals and populations.   Identify  individual, organizational and community concerns, assets, resources and  deficits for social and behavioral science interventions.   Identify  critical stakeholders for the planning, implementation and evaluation of  public health programs, policies and interventions.   Describe  steps and procedures for the planning, implementation and evaluation of  public health programs, policies and interventions.   Describe  the role of behavioral, social, cultural and structural factors in both  the onset and solution of public health problems.   Apply  evidence-based approaches in the development and evaluation of social and  behavioral science interventions.   Apply  ethical principles to public health research, program planning,  implementation and evaluation.   Specify  multiple targets and levels of intervention for social and behavioral  science programs and/or policies.   Evaluate  the roles of history, power, privilege and structural inequality in  producing health disparities.   Apply  public health research methods to the identification of social and  behavioral influences on health, and to the development of public health interventions,  program evaluations, and policy.                                              Degree Requirements                                               Course Sequences                                               Admissions Requirements                                                                   NYU Footer          Search      Directory      Campus Map         Feedback         Unless otherwise noted, all content copyright New York University. Statistics for the Social & Behavioral Sciences - NYU Libraries                               This is the "Statistics for the Social & Behavioral Sciences" guide.      Alternate Page for Screenreader Users      Skip to Page Content                                             Statistics for the Social & Behavioral Sciences         Last update: Feb 10, 2015        URL: http://guides.nyu.edu/content_mobile.php?pid=323498                                                                          Home                                                                                  For Additional Help                 Don't forget:   NYUAD Librarians are available to answer your questions via IM, email or in-person at the Information Desk.             Comments (0)                                         Welcome!                 Welcome to the Research Guide for Statistics in the Behavioral & Social Sciences! We have compiled a list of resources to facilitate your data search.   Data is a raw material of research in many disciplines. When you collect your own data (with a survey, observations, instruments, or countless other methods), we call that primary data. When you use data that others have collected for a new purpose, this is secondary data. This guide focuses on helping you find that secondary data that you can use for your own projects.   Before you start searching, a few questions to think about:     Who or what am I interested in? People? Commodities? Governments?   What geographical area am I interested in? at what level? Country? Region? City?   What time period(s) am I interested in?    Who would be likely to collect that data? Collecting data is expensive and time consuming!               Comments (0)                                              close                                                                                                          Finding Data                                                                                  Which sources should I use?                 If you want to look at a single variable across several countries/regions/cities , take a look at International Comparative Sources . Stick to one source for your comparison so that you can be sure the data was collected consistently (or normalized).   If you want to look at many variables or want to find very specific data within a country or region , use National Statistical Agencies or Country- or Region-Specific Sources .   If you're looking for data from surveys, public opinion polls, research studies, and more try Data Archives & Public Opinion Sources .           Comments (0)                                         NYU Data Resources                 Data Sources @ NYU   Links to sources of data and statistics available at NYU that can be explored by topic area.           Comments (0)                                         Adolescents & Education Data Sources                  The National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health (Add Health) A longitudinal study of a nationally representative sample of adolescents in grades 7-12 in the United States during the 1994-95 school year. The Add Health cohort has been followed into young adulthood with four in-home interviews, the most recent in 2008. National Center for Education Statistics The NCES (United States) is the primary federal entity for collecting and analyzing data related to education. Program for International Student Assessment (PISA) PISA is an international assessment that measures 15-year-old students' reading, mathematics, and science literacy. PISA also includes measures of general or cross-curricular competencies, such as problem solving. PISA emphasizes functional skills that students have acquired as they near the end of compulsory schooling. Trends in International Mathematics & Science Study (TIMSS) TIMMS provides reliable and timely data on the mathematics and science achievement of U.S. 4th- and 8th-grade students compared to that of students in other countries. TIMSS data have been collected in 1995, 1999, 2003, 2007, and 2011.            Comments (0)                                         Other Guides for Finding Data                  Health Statistics by Susan Jacobs International Statistics by Mary Jean Pavelsek International & Comparative Education - Statistical Resources by Scott Collard            Comments (0)                                         Sources for International Comparative Data & Statistics                  CEIC Data Manager CEIC Data contains economic, industrial and financial time-series data and cover 117 countries and regions including detailed data on China. Data comes from analysts on the ground and the prime national and regional statistical agencies and major industrial data issuing organizations of each country covered. Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) Data Includes EIU CountryData (278 series on 117 countries from 1980 to 2005), EIU CityData (pricing information on more than 160 products and services in 123 cities worldwide), EIU Market Indicators and Forecasts (industries, demographics, consumption, average wages, income levels, market size, infrastructure and the business environment data on 60 key countries worldwide), EIU World Investment Service (political and economic background, the business environment, business costs, foreign investment regulations, trends in foreign investment), and others. FRED: Federal Reserve Economic Data Offers a range of U.S. and international economic data from the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis. Includes price indexes, exchange rates, interest rates, GDP, trade balances, and more. International Financial Statistics Online The standard source of international statistics on all aspects of international and domestic finance. It reports, for most countries of the world, current data needed in the analysis of problems of international payments and of inflation and deflation, i.e., data on exchange rates, international liquidity, international banking, money and banking, interest rates, prices, production, international transactions, government accounts, and national accounts. This database contains time series data from 1948. International Programs (U.S. Census) Source for international census data. OECD iLibrary Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. (regularly updated). Publications portal of the OECD. Access to monographs and full text of all periodicals, as well as a statistical database. PRS CountryData Detailed political risk rankings, economic indicators and forecasts for over 160 countries Statista Statista aggregates data on markets, industry, politics, economics and population. Sources include trade publications, market and opinion research institutions, government sources, business and economic databases, reference publications, media sources and scholarly articles. It has an international scope and covers over 600 industries. Statistical Insight Indexing and some full text for many, but not all of the statistical publications of the U.S. Government and IGO's (Intergovernmental Organizations) such as the IMF, UN, OECD, World Bank and more. UNdata provides selected series from numerous specialized international data sources for all available countries and areas. World dataBank Gateway portal to the World Bank's World Development Indicators, Global Financial Database, and Africa Indicators. 500 time series indicators for 148 countries and regional and income groups, with basic indicators for a further 62 countries. Time series for most indicators cover 1960 to the present. IHS Global Insight Provides global economic, financial, and commodity information.                                              National Statistical Offices                  Central Banks Statistics Central banks publish bulletins that are predominantly or partially statistical in nature and provide many of these publications free of charge on the web. International Statistical Agencies Datas sources and links for national statistical offices around the world. UAE National Bureau of Statistics            Comments (0)                                         Data Archives & Public Opinion Sources                  Gallup Brain A searchable, living record of more than 70 years of public opinion research. Coverage is 1930 forward. ICPSR: Inter-University Consortium for Political and Social Research A data archive of more than 500,000 files of research covering many disciplines across the social sciences, including 16 specialized collections of data. Create a personal "MyData" account to download data files. Global Barometer Surveys A comprehensive effort to measure, at a mass level, the current social, political, and economic atmosphere around the world. It provides an independent, non-partisan, multidisciplinary view of public opinion on a range of policy-relevant issues. International Social Survey Programme A continuing annual programme of cross-national collaboration on surveys covering topics important for social science research. The data archive contains merged data from the different aspects of the programme. PUMS - Public Use Microdata Sample Provides harmonized data from 238 national censuses for 1960-present as well as data from U.S. census and American Community Surveys for 1850-present. Roper Center Public Opinion Archives Archives data sets from thousands of surveys with national adult, state, foreign, and special sub-population samples. World Values Survey The World Values Survey is administered to nationally representative samples covering values and perceptions of life, the environment, work, family, politics and society, religion and morale, and national identity, as well as demographic characteristics.            Comments (0)                                         Country- and Region-Specific Sources                  Africa Development Indicators Data in Africa Development Indicators have been gathered from a variety of sources to present a broad picture of development across Africa. Data are presented from 1965 for 53 African countries and 5 regional country groups, arranged in separate tables or matrices for more than 450 indicators. China Data Online Comprehensive database Web site focusing on economic statistics of China, arranged by regions and categories. Includes monthly and yearly reports on China's macroeconomic development, statistical databases about China's population and economy at the county and city level, and financial indicators of more than 568 industrial branches. Also includes statistical yearbooks, census data, industrial and marketing surveys, and an atlas of China. EuroStat Eurostat's mission is to provide high quality support for the seamless dissemination and efficient use of European statistical information as a public, non profit service within the European Statistical System (ESS). IndiaStat Statistics on health, higher education, agricultural and industrial production information, economic statistics, and tourism related data in India. The database also contains information bank and financial institutions, companies, co-operatives, crime and law, population, foreign trade, labour and workforce, housing, media, power, transport, urban-rural settlements and economy in India and more. Click on "IP LOGIN" button to authenticate U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics The Bureau of Labor Statistics is the principal fact-finding agency for the Federal Government in the broad field of labor economics and statistics. SAGE Stats SAGE Stats is a data visualization and research platform hosting extensive social science data collections. The data collections contain data series based on time and geography. All of the data series are standardized and normalized allowing you to find, compare, visualize, and export. SAGE Stats currently hosts two data collections: State Stats and Local Stats. These data collections contain data from more than 100 different government and non-government sources to create a rich collection of more than 6,000 current and historical data series on high-interest research topics. Dating back more than 20 years, each data series is displayed in a clear and consistent format with detailed source information.            Comments (0)                                              close                                                                                                          Using Statistical Software                                                                                  R, STATA & SPSS @ NYU AD                 R, STATA, and SPSS software can be accessed on the Mac and PC computers on the second floor of the NYUAD Library.   Please ask at the Information Desk if you have any questions about using this software.           Comments (0)                                         Contact the Data Service Studio                 NYU Data Service Studio   data.service@nyu.edu   From an on-campus phone, dial 50-83434 . Remember that New York is 8 hours behind Abu Dhabi during Daylight Savings Time and 9 hours behind during standard time.   Bobst Library 5th Floor (NYU-NY)   Appointment/question form           Comments (0)                                         Resources for Learning Stata                 Useful Websites for Learning Stata       Resources for Learning Stata - A collection of official and user-written training materials.   UCLA Statistical Computing (Stata) - A variety of learning modules, FAQ and case examples of using Stata for statistical computing.     "Introduction to Stata" tutorial from the NYU Data Service Studio       Tutorial Documentation (.pdf) - A guide that covers the basics of data management in Stata (version 11).   Example Do File (.do) - An example .do file used in the introduction to Stata tutorial.   Example Do File (.do) - Another example .do file used for the introduction to Stata tutorial.             Comments (0)                                         Statistical Software E-books                 This ebook can provide guidance in using Stata:   The Stata Survival Manual - David Pevalin; Karen Robson ISBN: 0335223877 Publication Date: 2009            Comments (0)                                              close                                                                                                          Citing Data                                                                                  How Should I Cite Data Sets?                 Citation standards for data sets are still evolving, but you have a few options:     Use the format of a style manual, such as APA .   Use the data archive or source's preferred citation.     Remember that the purpose is to help your reader re-trace your steps -- more information is better than less!           Comments (0)                                         Citing Data Sets Using APA Style                 APA (American Psychological Association)   Point readers to raw data by providing a Web address (use "Retrieved from") or a general place that houses data sets on the site (use "Available from").     General format:   Author/Rightsholder. (Year). Title of data set (Version number) [Description of form]. Retrieved from http://   OR   Author/Rightsholder. (Year). Title of data set (Version number) [Description of form]. Location: Name of producer.   Examples:   United States Department of Housing and Urban Development. (2008). Indiana income limits [Data file]. Retrieved from http://www.huduser.org/Datasets/IL/IL08/in_fy2008.pdf     United Nations Statistics Division. (2008). Gender Info 2007 . [Data file]. Retrieved from http://data.un.org/Data.aspx?d=GenderStat&f=inID%3a12 Economist Intelligence Unit. (2012). EIU CountryData . [Data file]. London: Economist Intelligence Unit.   Partially adapted from The Owl at Purdue. (2012). "APA Style: Reference List: Electronic Sources (Web Publications)." Retrieved from http://owl.english.purdue.edu/owl/resource/560/10/            Comments (0)                                         Use the Preferred Citation from Your Data Source                 Some data providers, such as archives or some government agencies, prefer that you cite their data a certain way. Look around on their webpage for clues.   For example, ICPSR provides a citation for each dataset on the Study Description page:     In this case, you can just copy and paste the citation right into your bibliography!           Comments (0)                                         Why Should You Cite Your Sources?                 All scholarly or academic work requires  that you cite your sources, whether you are writing a long paper or a quick report. Why is citing your research so important?   Researching and writing a paper ideally involves a process of exploring and learning. By citing your sources, you are showing your reader how you came to your conclusions and acknowledging the other people's work that brought you to your conclusions. Citing your sources:      Documents your research and   scholarship    Acknowledges the work of others   whose scholarship contributed to your work    Helps your reader understand   the context of your argument    Provides information for your   reader to use to locate additional information on your topic    Establishes the credibility of   your scholarship   Provides you with an opportunity to demonstrate your own integrity and understanding of academic ethics        Partially adapted from "When and Why to Cite Sources." SUNY Albany. 2008.       Retrieved 14 Jan 2009. http://library.albany.edu/usered/cite/citing.html .           Comments (0)                                         More resources for citing data                  Why and how should I cite my data? Comments (0)                                         R, STATA & SPSS @ NYU AD                 R, STATA, and SPSS software can be accessed on the Mac and PC computers on the first floor of the NYUAD Library.   Please ask at the Information Desk if you have any questions about using this software.           Comments (0)                                         About the NYU Data Service Studio                 The Data Service Studio (DSS) is a joint ITS and Libraries service that supports quantitative, qualitative and geographical research at NYU. The DSS offers access to specialty software packages, statistical and GIS training and support, and consulting expertise for many aspects of numerical and spatial data for research, including data access, analysis, collection, data management and preservation.   The Data Service Studio facility is located at NYU's Washington Square campus in New York, NY, but can provide virtual assistance for patrons located at NYU Abu Dhabi. AD patrons may use any of the contact methods described below, but should be aware that you will receive an answer only during DSS staffed hours, which are 6pm-2am Abu Dhabi time.   You can find the DSS on the 5th floor of Bobst Library. It is equipped with 26 lab workstations and is designed for students, faculty and staff to receive consultation help and access to statistical analysis, GIS, qualitative and survey research software.   Consultation is available by appointment through the online appointment form via email ( data.service@nyu.edu ), telephone (212-998-3434), or on a walk-in basis. Information on upcoming tutorials, clinics, and other events is available by subscribing to the ITS/FTS Statistics and GIS Group Listserv at: join-statistics@lists.nyu.edu (send a blank, plain text, e-mail, or sign up for the list within the NYU Home portal).           Comments (0)                                         Contact the Data Service Studio                 NYU Data Service Studio   data.service@nyu.edu   From an on-campus phone, dial 50-83434 . Remember that New York is 8 hours behind Abu Dhabi during Daylight Savings Time and 9 hours behind during standard time.
